turonense pope calleth bishop rome place king dooth forbidde go commaundeth come court vntruth author speaketh tvvo councels councellthe king obeied ecclesiastical cause pope bisshoppes muste obey kinges precept onely case matter euer besides sinne dooth obserue bounden fidelitie kinge whether bisshoppethe vntruthe quitinus auouched suche thinge priest deacon throwne foorth degree place proufe vvhereof citeth many canon decree concludeth thus briefe mine opinion whan kinge calleth together prelate councell reforme state church bounde obey yea although pope vntruth meant feudis regalibus haue quyte left quintinus forbidde stapleton olde matter calling coucels prince wherin see authour maketh general absolut rule doe certayne tymes consideration greatly stande yowe seinge authour confesseth stand ye stande prince coucels hath superiority interesse tame volo reges tantu non praeesse talibus sacerdotum co uentibus cleargy saith wil prince present councelles president therfor quintinus wil aduocat bishop priesthod promised woulde enacte nothing synodes without king consente yet haue ye one prety knacke quintinus proue king supreame head pope kinge one syde pope side call bisshops councell bisshoppes muste obey kinge pope onely thinge thinges euer beside synne happie ye haue putte beside synne putteth quite beside cusshion say beside matter purpose synne yea one moste horrible kindes synne schisme prince anie holde councell contrary councell summoned lawfull pope neuer anie good successe ecclesiasticall story euery reporte aaron rodde deuoured roddes iamnes mambres sorcerer aegipte num rodde onely among roddes schismaticall murmuringe people israell geue forth yong slippesal schismaticall coucels fayne legth yelde pope cou cell braunches memoriall reserued tabernacle euen councells pope gathered allowed haue deuoured abolished vnlawful schismaticall conuenticles onely florish estimation shalbe euer preserued tabernacle christes catholyke churche walke larg felde matter lieth open frenche kinges doinges onely whereof ye talke shall sufficiente confirmation side story onely self haue browght forth stregthnig ye thought purpose coucel rhemes kig hugo capet assembled deposing ther ye write bishop arnulphus issue horn fol io mari de schism concil differ par cap benedictus summone coucel eue city ad restored arnulph al fayre kig philip attepted agaist pope bonifaci coucels frace brought naught coucel sumoned pope haue declared haue also shewed latera councell abolished pisane conuenticle lewes frenche king others maynteyned self write wherfore yf authour thus writen neither tyme auncient authoritie great man might haue sayde wonderfully deceyued false sleight craftie coueiance deceyue reader authour speaketh two councells one summoned pope king speaketh bishop held fealty homage land king sayth quoad feuda regalia concernig theis fealty royalty ide quintinus aristocrat fo paris quatenus ad feuda regalia pertinet per glosam ca reprehensibile qu king aboue bisshops aboue vassal therfore pope one side send bisshoppe kinge side send concerning fealty homage matter ought goe king otherwise shoulde rather obey pope king appereth sayth quintine glose referreth hym self theis wordes feuda regalia haue ye sliely slipt ouer though quintinus auouched bishop subiectio ecclesiastical matter could otherwise haue decked margent gay freshe lying note king obeyed ecclesiastical cause pope ye sodainly become spiritual good ecclesiastical manm horne leaueth vvhich serueth opening vvhole matter feuda regalia become matter ecclesiastical true ye may rightfully called ecclesiastical man hauing madge owne kepe back warme cold winter nightes good reason ye may cal ecclesiastical woman horn diuision pag people doth amende reforme negligence pastour vlt dist ergo prince also may bisshop wil doe forslovve heare decide controuersies cleargy bisshop slowe tarying ouer longe nothing dooth hinder stay saith canon aske episcopale iudicium bisshoply iudgement emperour happen priest diligent aultar office concerning temple neglecting sacrifice hasten king palayces runne wrastlinge place doe prophane selues brothelles house yf conuert faithful haue offred pleasure selues wherefore shal prince whome catholique faith hath begotten taught bosome church cal againe take vpon selues care matter proueth large many example history lavves care charge ecclesiasticall vntruth chardge ecclesiastical matter aboute ecclesiastical person temporal matter external order kept execution church canon requiringe pri ce ayde c matter cause belongeth prince vnto vvhich example addeth father tyme saith kinge lewes made constitution archebisshoppes bisshops abbottes euer hadde dignity church cure benefice within fiue monethes resorte church remoue fro diligently labouring diuine matter sacrifice faulfty king kingdome vnder great paine losing good land quintinus doth greuously complain dissolute moste vvho corrupt nevve clergy handycraft minister corrupt maners cleargy vvhereto addeth saying vvherefore prince co pell iewde idle kinde men dueties stapleton may people horne amende reforme negligence pastour pope lawe tom horn impertinent allegation belyke headlesse people germany headlesse bretherne late haue made ruffle lowe countres shal finde good defence doings saue reast gybet sacke haue yet passed way may yt seme smal matter laye people haue late acte parliamente transformed altered olde relligion minde bisshops whole conuocation authour saieth ecclesiae nihil est licentius democratia worlde nothing perniciouse church god vnbrideled libertie people dist docendus must taught followed alleageth pope celestin ad two distinctios distinction self alleage great reformation horn distinction speaketh content yf bisshops others negligent prince may compell doe dewty loke wel self negligent aultars hovve handsomly h pleadeth selfe worthy punished therfore throwe downe aultars neglect sacrifice yow deny sacrifice presence christ sacramet fellowes co uerte pleasure selues theires faithful hath offred christ laying church good vpo self haue parte become mariage laye man mainteyninge ad purchasing whiche signifieth constraine compel dyd kinge dyd require demaunde touching emperour charles suppose sufficiently answered alrerdye nothing answered youre selfe nowe alleage maie serue good answere maketh newe rule constitution churche matter establissheth reneweth olde saieth wil compell men lyue according rule canon father neither doothe call selfe heade gouernoure churche deuoute defender concluded pope tooke authoritie laie men prouing contrarye selfe ministreth good matter selfe horne diuision pag bbraughto lib cap de papa archiepiscopis alijs praelat besydes lavviers vvas common opinion chiefest vvriters comon lavv realme appeareth vntruth contrary appeareth plainely braughton shal declared braughton vvoordes sunt sub rege c vnder king bothe freeman bondemen subiect power vnder certaine thing creature vnder none onely vnder god againe chapiter title vvhereof rex non habet parem c king hath peere equall kingdome king saith kingdom hath equall might lose precepte authoritie commaunding sithe equall hathe rule commaundement ouer equall king himselfe ought vnder man vnder god vnder law law maketh king let king therefore attribute vnto lawe lawe attributeth vnto himthe vntruth parte sentence opening ansvvering vvhole obiection nipped quite wit dominion power king law doth rule ought vnder law cum sit dei vicarius sith vicare god appeareth euidently likenes iesu christe whose vicegerent earth vvithin litle concludeth thus igitur non debet maior esse eo regno suo therfore ought none greater kingdome chapter concerning braughton maister horne last authour stapleton happie horne writeth english english men latine surelye oure countrie hath shutte pope authoritie yea ad al maner ecclesiastical authority shal passe ocean sea towarde may al nation muche better exclude authority temporall lawyer realme passe sayde ocean sea toward christian belief pity become late nothing else parliamet matter matter commo lawe seing haue estraunged self olde comon churche pope horne may proue contrary assertio braughton dare offerre fekenhams name shal take othe wil self dare promise much ad wil performe shalbe contete withal horne highe inuentio shal made cause proue clerely pope primacy euen author chapter maister horne alleaged cap leo strayned horn speake somewhat prince supremacy matter ecclesiastical hath spoken done much proue primacy see rome horn wil stand owne author vtterly confounded forced agnise pope primacy without maner doubte cap example also martian emperour calling chalcedon councell nextly alleaged horn purpose whit furdered pope leo primacy euidently proued cap actes also sayd councell pope bishop supreme iurisdiction al ecclesiastical matter treated examined iudged defined throughe whole councel appeareth horne purpose remayneth vtterly vnproued cap haue farder sayd chalcedon councell fourthe generall one foure allowed countre acte parliament reigne queenes mai present elizab gathered euident sundry argumentes proufe pope bishop supremacy cause ecclesiasticall require horne man el whatsoeuer shewe howe possible without manifeste contradiction allowe authorytie fourthe generall councel bannishe pope authorytie whole councel agnised geue prince supreme authorytie al ecclesiastical cause councel resting bishop prince hath consequently ben shewed horne cap exaples leo zeno emperours haue proued nothing lesse imagined supremacy next example three pope simplicius cap felix symachus haue al proued manifest testimony owne supremacy euen bookes place horne alleaged matter semeth plaine preuaricatour one secretly defending cause seemeth openly impugne nowe fraunce horne cap lucke hath bene better east church italy argument behalfe haue bene pelting miserable bishop iurisdiction matter hath bene euident story iustinus elder nextly alleaged cap confusedly measure mangled wholy layed forthe hath plainely proued pope supremacy nothing al prince iustinian next exaample cap largely prosecuted hath neuer whit proued matter pope absolute supremacy hath diuerse way pronounced onelye behauyour fifte generall councell edictes constitution selfe thicke haue alleaged fol place also haue noted diuerse exaples euil successe churche matter haue fol whe prince intermedled ther also way councell fraunce horne alleaged hath openly pronounced pope vniuersall supremacy cap last example taken spayne haue nothinge relieued badde cause haue geuen euidet witnesse bishop supremacy ecclesiastical cause thus farre haue waded first yeres christe without one prouf newe laicall supremacy pope bishop supremacy matter church cotinual practise first age al countres hath clerely pronounced hath bene large shewed third book race runne longer ad triple ye ranne cause stroger febler rather wretcheder copasse yeres many emperor king prince many coucels general national diuerse part christened worlde al east part italy fraunce spayne germany countre englad yea moscouites armenia aethyopias say one prince councel coutre maketh one prince councell countre maketh v haue agnised pope primacy one worlde many hundred yeres haue agnised muche hearde muche lesse sworen vnto prince supreme gouuernement ecclesiasticall cause first proufe belyeth flatly see rome cap proueth nothing phoca emperour supremacy woulde proue kinges spayne toletane councelles haue made nothinge cap haue clerely confounded principal matter hande also diuers matter lewde heresy denied patched proufes swarming vntruthes next narratio touching certain pope rome cap churche rauena haue discouered miserable wekenesse badde cause nothing relieued yowe pope primacy owne example notwithstanding established fonde surmise decree constantin emperour prerogatiue see apostolike cap nothing furdered matter hande yf bene made shewed wel misery cause make paradoxe beare credit fayne discredit al historias writer matter calling papistes pope parasite fayners wrote practise ecclesiasticall gouernement vsed sixt general councel next alleaged cap cofirmeth word dede pope primacy bisshops supreme iurisdiction matter ecclesiasticall geueth forth maner inckling imagined supremacy matter beside twenty vntruthes vttered much confounded councell countre notwithstanding great obiection pope honorius haue sufficiently aunswered cap talke three king spayne next ensewing three toletane councells kept reignes doth litle disproue supreme iurisdiction bisshops ecclesiastical cause maketh supreme iudges euen ciuil cause wide euer prouing purpose cap general councel shortly noted doth amply abundantly confirme pope primacy nothing worlde helpeth purpose cap martel ad carolomanus sonne exercised whit imagined supremacy haue cofessed clerely pope primacy doings eue matter self treated ignorant ridiculous exposition made keyes peter confession sent charles extreme fonde argument deducted thereof hath vtterly shamed yf shame cap slaunderous reproches augustine apostle boniface apostle germany holye martyr haue redounded owne shame follye cause thereby nothing worlde furdered yf yt bene true hadde reported cap callinge councelles confirmynge publishinge churche lawes practised yet anye like gouuernement ecclesiasticall cause haue defended anye gouuernement lead gouerned selfe suche thinges father bisshoppes liuing especiallye see rome whole order also councelles alleaged hath plainelye condemned prophane maner determinyng cause ecclesiasticall nowe vsed mere laye men warrant suche yowe pope primacye none clere charlemaine bothe doinges vide fol b b ite fol cap cause pope leo sayinges booke much fellowes alleaged decree appeareth lewys first sonne charlemayne practised parte supremacye pope tyme hadde full vse thereof pope fithens confirmation persecuted true pope thought intruded pope neuer made question whether ought obeye see apostolike doubted true elected pope tooke parte worste side question nowe dayes farre vnlike proufes horne farre beginne course well brytannie saxon coming england called pope primacy clerely confessed practised euen day amonge catholikes euery gouernement william conquerour william rufus sonne kinge henry first hath bene proued farre vnlike pretende right appertayne crowne englande yea prince whatsoeuer pope supreme gouernement spirituall matter example yea euen testimony owne authours expressely proued lie proue purpose foloweth armenian aethyopians cap proueth also moste euidently pope supremacy country proueth whit singular paradoxicall primacy verely singular one parte vniuersall worlde founde doinges king stephen kinge henry cap haue proued pope supremacy coutre kinde supremacy imagine make proufe worlde martyrdome thomas way also defended ad fox lewed lying matter cap philip otho emperor lewed lying foxe hath bene partly discouered touchinge kinge iohn matter fraunce time haue proued pope primacy prince cap discourse friderike doinges principall cause hath taken great foyle mayne number heresy authours owne supreme head condemned haue geue great cracke al religion beside cap time kinge henry condemneth alltogether primacy booke defended pronounceth clerely pope supremacy lewys bauary much bable cap hath nothinge relieued neither yet poetes petrarche dante greate strife aboute pope temporall primacy spirituall superiorytie neuer yet kinge christened denied vntill late dayes owne countre meanes apostatas haue hearde also place horne enumeratio al emperours cap notoriously haue rebelled see apostolike god iudgement hath bene ouer euill endes came god vengeaunce cap valoys composuit rem sacerdotum yet maketh nothing purpose owne matter concluded againste otherwise mere spirituall iurisdictions neuer intermedled claymed vse thereof spirituall magistrate owne authours witness paulus aemylius petrus bertrandus haue deposed againste owne kinge philippe hath condemned cap edwarde richarde england al reporte nauclere polidore haue nothwithstandinge pronounced face horne woulde shame haue brought open courte prouerbe looke howe haue brewed must bake shall say last witness cap catholike bisshoppes doctours owne countre quintinus paris petrus ferraria last philippus decius lawier brawghton countreman extreme vncourtesy may wel say impudency hath bene part violently desperatly drawe barre right sure condemned verdicte thought might frame tale man woulde comptrol extreme lying preface say thus haue truly shortly repeted vnto horne haue done haue done require worlde yf intende replye answer euery particular haue done proue selfe honest man fovrth booke conteyning fvl confvtation horne answeres made fekenhams reason taking othe supremacye diuision pag b fekenham secod point seconde chief point must vpon booke othe testifie also declare cosciece queenes highnesse supreame gouernour realme aswel spiritual ecclesiasticall thing cause temporall vpon booke othe make declaration conscience may possible vvithout periury man coscience perswaded thereunto therefore conscience yet persuaded thereunto presently without plaine manifest periury receiue othe horne difference matter betvvixt tvvo proposition testifie conscience declare conscience although seeme subtile vntruthe fekenham maketh difference farre diuerse shal appeare vvould haue simple conceiue vvay amplification much diuersitie euen vvhich ye call second chiefe point varieth vntruthe varieth muche vvhitte matter first therefore former ansvveare serueth ye vvil needes make tvvo shevv dede one first chapter conteyning fekenhams first reason taken actes apostle way king lucius stapleton hitherto hath horne twety ful leaues enlarged proufs touchig co firmatio newe ecclesiastical superiority hitherto hath assaide al force beate ground pope primacy yet notwithstading al terrible assaulte standeth strog sure euer yea trust stroger ad surer withal indifferetly haue perused ad waighed two former labour horn wil playe lustly defendatm horne novv begineth play defendats parte wherin seemeth make light al fekenhas argument take strength weight fether seing hath alredy take many foyles many woundes semeth weapon haue rashe hardines wel beaten himselfe setting vpon aduersarie hard yt beare blowes aduersary wil bestowe vpo neither thinke good reader shall euer soyle men reason soundly sothly confirme owne yet let v trie howe wil shifte self see howe euen first entraunce playeth fowle playe wrangleth fekenham doth make difference betwixte testifie conscience declare conscience maister horne sayeth dothe betwixte take othe queenes maiesty supreame heade cause declare conscience two thing man maye many doe pity take othe feare loue rewarde quyte contrary coscience nede seke farre example euen matter supremacy nowe hande withal though therefore may perswaded many pitie pretence obedience feare displeasure loue worldly promotion rich pleasure take othe yet declare conscience man possibly maister fekenham trulye reasoneth without manifest periury except conscience persuaded thereunto persuade conscience requireth either soden reuelation miraculouse inspiration god presumed without euident signe thereof el tract time instructed informed taught neuer lerned fekenham therefore ad al feare god haue lerned ghospell forsake father mother wyfe child good landes al worlde dere christes sake euery truth concerning christian religion say neither inspired god soden reuelation neither preaching writing yet informed instructed possibly though thousand act parliament commaund declare conscience declare say conscience hart thought beleue verely supreme gouernement prince act expresseth intedeth may perswaded take othe externall fact external respect force feare fraylty perswaded declare othe conscience man without internall persuasion hart minde co trary internall perswasion consent whiche power prince force act law statut worldly euer make euer declareth externallye booke othe worde mouth thinketh incurreth manifestly horrible crime periurie ad double periurie god wil neuer suffer vnreueged without hartie repetance strog inuincible reaso horn answereth word maketh reader beleue fekenham putteth difference betwen testifiyng coscience declaring coscience doth thus betwene testifiyng boke othe declaring conscience putteth true difference haue said largely well horne hath pleaded perswade fekenhams conscience thou seest good reader thou haue diligetly read coferred proufes confutation doubt many catholike men wil perswaded conscience least neuer take othe whiche singularlie contrarie christendome beside doe defende fekenham againe according prophet king thou hast loued righteosnes hated iniquitie wherefore god euen thy god hath anointed thee oile gladnes aboue thy fellowes againe according prophet kinge geue kinge thy iudgement god thy righteousnes vnto kinges sonne geue iugement righteousnes caesar christian nation people kingdome kinges sonnes dwel consiste kingdome vnder protection peace according gospel euen henne gathereth together chickes vnder winges nation indede kingdom britany people ad diuided ought gather together concorde peace faith lawe christ holy church reuoke cherishe mainteine protect rule vvretchedly horne handleth storie themperour philip come good horne declare v surely good reader neuer beare came stake worse maister horne wil come nigh point come one nigh shal forthwith declare theyr faultes stande amonge penytentes wherevnto obeyed gladly declaring euen horne writeth theyr dedes workes feare god perfect christian faith horne feare god yea christia faith besides confession sinnes place penitentes storie hath also testimonie sacrifice churche pope clergy supreamacie ouer princethe cause moued horne handle story stoutlie denie making prince supreme al cause without exception therefore without faith feare god ye haue stollen away conueied sight reader darke cacus denne like pageant yea excedingly much worse plaie storie noble first christian king lucius beda li eccles hist ca misit ad eum lucius britanoru rex epistolam obsecrans vt per eius mandatu efficeretur christian ide prorsus damasus pontificali ye doe onely slie sluttish silence dissemble doings pope eleutherius ye pope fabian impudentelye auouche king lucius thing mentioned polidore whiche christening whole nation chiefe consequentlye christened without knowledge consent pope eleutherius bring foorth horne one authour greke latine english good badd new old catholike heretike vnlesse perchaunce may shew one late brother write yet long search find none writeth ye write content though al euident notoriouselie remitte next reckoning whiche yet better keping accopt must let passe vnscored neuer readde neuer readde chronicler newe olde galf monumetes epistolas eleuthe io papae direxi petens vt ab eo christianitatem reciperet li ca galfr monum c asse ius meueues annalibus angl vnlesse yt late bretherne catholikes write copediously yt abridgmetes thinges doth expressely write king lucius sent rome pope eleutherius might aduice authority christened negatiue thereof neuer say read shal trowe fynde madde maliciouse writer ye write yt againe referre owne countremen beda writeth eleutherius bishop rome desiring sende deuoute learned man whose instruction people might tawghte faith religion christ superfluouse ouerlade answere reader external latin writer nauclerus sabellicus platina iohannes laziardus abbas vrspergensis ado especially damasus vita eleutherij ad nuber like agree chronicle perchaunce wil thinke mayster horne would neuer impudent gainsay theis wryters chronicler fetcheth narration towching lucius owte polidorus hath leaste pointe polidorus side yf though yt foolish fond shifte yet yt somwhat colourable shifte self notable lie polidorus writeth conformably yt true mayster horne boroweth residewe polidorus moste wretchedlie dismembreth residewe polidorus narration polidorus lib iste anno salutis humanae regni vero verae religionis amore ductus cu eleutherio romano pontifice egit vt se ac suos ad christianoru numeru coelesti sonte perfusos adiungeret missi sunt eo fugatius ac damianus viri pietate singulari hij rege cum tota domo populo que vniuerso baptisarunt sublatoque c towcheth pope eleutherius lucius sayeth polidore yeare lorde yeare reigne verie true loue religion sent letter eleutherius pope procure people might made christian fugatius damianus men singular vertue sente thither baptise kinge al courte people hath horne broken cutte myddle sentence thereby hath mangled torne miserablie euer medea chylde well sawe yt made notablye pope primacy whiche shall well perceyue yf doe deaplye consider cause moued kynge sende farre rome see good reader sincere honest dealing horne consideration cause moued lucius send rome man woulde firste sight thinke doinges king straunge namely considering abowt time liued fraunce great clearke bishoppe ireneus many famouse men whose ayde might haue craued necessary instruction christian faith neither lacke home owne subiectes could well yt semeth haue serued turne yet doubte good kinge good substantial grownde doinges cosidered anon death christe euer vntil lucius time amonge christian number heretikes whiche bore name christian theyre heresy loste benefitte christedome simonians schollers simon magus menandrians saturninians basilidians nicolaites heretikes called gnostici excellent knowledge pretended haue aboue cherinthians cerdonias phrygian montanistes marcionites diuerse eche secte contending theire owne false faith true niceph li c onely christian faith yea manie taken prophetes montanus others many suffred death christe catholike great pacience among priest called metrodorus marcionite idem li cap secte euen lucius time great number suffred persecution raised christian whereof secte craked muche euseb li cap made thereof great argument true faith muche better argumete doth mayster foxe madde martyr died moste wilfullie playne open heresie lucius vnderstading good cause careful receiued christendome least chauncing vppo false shrew taking instructour might rather chaunge one errour put yt cleane away idolatour become false christian wante good choyse instructours cause valens emperour became arrian suche horrible bloudsucker catholikes also cause gothes ad vadales arrias cruelly afflicted martyred thowsandes christian sureste way lucius auoyde daunger dowbtles toke send churche rome neuer erred faith principal churche al church muste agree reason cheif principalitie churche ireneus blessed bishop martyr wrote euen tyme lucius principalitie say hath troubled horne durst truely reporte owne authour yea amased falling sodely rage hath framed v suche open maliciouse lie euer wil hereafter truste well worthie beguiled wil ye yet see greate madnes man moste shamefully denieth theis doinges lucius pope eleutherius againste vniforme cosente al historiographer hath fownde letter lucius eleutherius answerecocernig pope eleutherius letter king lucius wherof one al foresayde chronicler maketh mention ca yet lerne containinge matter altogether vnprobable vnlikely therefore mete fowrtene hundred yeares nowe length come owte trophonius cacus blinde denne set horne boke notable matter antiquity furnish bewtify new supremacie withal layeth v forth epistle eleutherius authour hath taken yt forraine power authority christian man doe directly two article crede credo sanctum ecclesia catholica beleue holy catholik hurch credo sanctoru comunione beleue comunio saint participatio comunion amongest al beleuers christes church apostle paule called saincts adiuro vos per dominu vt legatur haec epistola omnibus sanctis fratribus herin ioyne issue l wha l shalbe able proue scripture doctor general coucell cotinual practise one church part al christe dome first article beleue holy catholik church meant catholike church christ article euery christia man bound subiect obedient catholike church like euery member ought haue obediece vnto whole mystical bodie christ shall hable proue second article dooe beleue communion saint meante christian man oughte beleeue attonement suche participation communion amongest al beleeuers member christes catholike churche doctrine faith religion sacramentes laufull v realme therein dissent catholike churche christe dispersed realmes corporal othe laufull v renounce refuse haue communion catholike church dispersed bycause forrayne authoritie power realme soeuer l shalbe hable proue scripture doctour generall councell yet continuall practise one church parte al christendome shal lyke manner yelde third point humble thankes shal thinke selfe well satisfied therein horne thirde chiefe pointe vntruth conteineth argumet horne shal neuer assoyle nothing el misshapened lumpe vvordes conteining firste argument grounded vppon kinde opposition vvise learned man euer redde nevvelie forged hammered ovvne braine issue haue prooue thinge vvhiche beinge rightly vnderstanded christian doth doubte vvill denie laste huge heape flatte manifeste vntruth slaunderous iniurious lye againste vvhole realme set good face vppon euill fauoured cause vvhich finde helpe ease plaine simple truthe vveightie burden loden vvith beare must othe renounce foreine povver authoritie cause maketh fainte feeble directly againste tvvo artiles creede feeble reason grounded simple skill vppon place ab oppositis pugnantibus aunsvvere argument vvill put reader remembraunce diuision vvhiche make chopping chaunginge one vntruth diuers article one clemes compend de fide article tvvaine make shevve heinous matter surely vvere ouermuche detestable vvere moued svveare one article creede yee vvere neuer moued either fro svveare anie thinge three symboles creedes vvhiche haue bene allovved receaued christes catholique churche symbole apostle nicen councell athanasius apostolicall called bycause vvas collected saye tvvelue apostle therefore conteineth commonly receiued opinion christes churche according number tvvelue apostle tvvelue article vvhiche called vsuall speache catholique christian tvvelue article creede beliefe beleue communion sainctes seuerall article beleue holy catholique churche doe phantasie muste needes leaste thirtene article creede contrarie vntruth como opinio lerned rekoneth article vniuersally receiued opinion catholique churche vvere vvonte staye selfe muche vpon custome catholike churche vvoulde vrge stiflie although trulie vniuersallie receiued opinion catholique churche matter might bee reiected denied hovve chaunceth novve become suche chaungeling cleane vntruth contrarie vse catholike church vvhiche acknovvledged tvvelue vvil make thirtene article creede leaste besides th catholike paral iosephus antiq l cap vlt definitio descriptio catholik church ye bring much lyke shooe serueth euery fote welshman hose serueth euery legge simon magus marcion hebion manicheus photinus arrius offering sacrifice made ther hierusalem iewes sayth iosephus vnlawfully maried transgressed violated sabbot day eaten meates thing contrary lawe fearing punishment would fly samaritanes false bishop forewarde brethern went backewarde valecene first chief rebelling towne wythin ix dayes taken preacher within xiiij dayes bothe sacramentary lutheran haue voyded towne yea whole countre god praised vnity peace concorde diuision pag fekenham fourth last point must swere obseruatio othe quenes highnes ad soueraign lady also vnto heyers successours king queenes realme bicause euery christian man ought carefull auoid periurie therein would right gladly knowe highnes successours refusall said title supremacie bind subiects like statute lawe vnto cleane contrarie experience whereof late made realme yet freshe memory men case would right gladly knowe authoritie able dispence againe othe none subiectes realme case bounde booke othe liue continuall disobedience lawes soueraigne lord ladie king quene case wherof lamentable christian charity would shoulde foreseene prouided mine owne parte touched herein haue yet expressed trust hope charity newe refourmed churche realme shal found colde shorte prouiding sharpe lawes paine death force men take othe quenes highnes supreamacie prouide also meanes wayes wherby subiects may receiue safe coscience without al periurie shal willingly submit selfe receiue also part othe shall therevpon set foorth quenes highnes supremacie al title prerogatiues bothe penne worde mouth desirous harte glad subiect day liuing highnesse realme premiss ye may well vnderstande mee cause staie touching later part othe conscience would right gladly know touching forenamed point might sweare vnto committe periurie therein ho ne euerie christian man ought carefull auoide periurie al matter euen vvise men may vvell knovve vvhat meane conditionall case ye put refusall highnesse successours title vvhereto holy ghoste maketh plaine ansvver spes hypocritae peribit hypocrite hope shall perishe sprinkle doubtfull case vvith pouder late experience vhiche seasoneth mater de facto non de iure lavvfull christian prince refuse vntruth lauful price take vestra horne nota sit omnibus hominibus svvine grunte groine ovvne self haue perfect experiece supreme gouernour vnder christ realm folovving exaple heauely father doth boutifully goodnes vvith much patiece log sufferig allure dutiful repetace hath prouided sundry meanes vvaies vvherby remoue vvilful ignorance endue vvith sufficient knovvledge truthe hovv ye might vvith salfe conscience receiue dutifull othe true subiecte vvithout periurie chapter fekenhams fourth chiefe point stapleton diuisio lie raile blasphemously horribly eue satha presetly entred pro pted vnto backe cacred matter poisoned hart hath coceiued ad also foul termes spritish pen hath endited fekenha demauded reasonable demaund case take new found othe chauce prince successours bind subiects like statute law cleane cotrary might dispensed withal horne stede good reaso fal detestable railing ye say oth must wise geue pope perillous enemy vnto christ turke poperie idolatrous turkery blasphemouse answere yf yt true yt must necessary consequente follow al catholik prince liue either liued englande sence first christened augustin apostle else christedome hundred yeares people haue bene idolatours worse turkes liked well enquiring age heard fifty yeres old would turke yonger tyme shoulde perhaps one come luther shoulde fynde good lord whe luther heard blessed selfe saied god saue good lorde yea euen day luther hath many schollers dehorteth christian resiste turkes especially claudius monerius one late holie martyr newe ghospelling church misliketh christian men defence vide crispinum historia pseudomartyru lib claudio monerio make withstad turke saieth knightes rhodes nothing graf heauenly father neuer graffed therefore owght plucked vp roote let man nowe merueill yf turkes prosper againste christias seing hath suche frendes home amonge selues wherof horne one least goliath much worse desperatly arrogantlie defying reuiling host liuing god whole catholike churche much vilanously trayterously sayd wicked philistian sworen professed enemy people god therefore therein kinde professing selfe fried also captaine christian army place occupie considered beare thereunto deuelish philistian harte turkish christian penne hath vttered yet yf ye proued thing answere derogation pope authority religion mainteineth men eares woulde lesse haue glowed heare talke turkishlie haue dede great brauery talke horrible woordes withowt substantiall proufe matter ye take hande yea ye rather ouerborne beaten downe number owne allegation authority place iob ye alleage hypocrite hope shall perishe doth touche fekenham fellowes yt touche blessed man iob baldad vntruely charge yt ye doe baldly vntruely charge nowe catholikes therwith catholiks haue almost one thousand yeres quietly possessed enioyed faith realme ye peuishely prowdly call popery religion ye professe hath yet continewed vnder anie one prince tenne yeares together miracle ye worke none though many woders ye worke procedinges altogether wondered neither lyfe sect vertuouse learning greate either wyse men suche haue feare god may sodenly drawen theire aunciente catholike faith ye may binde prince nowe lyuing theire successours suche turkish answere reasonable demaunde may wise mainteyne faith notoriously commonly mainteyned englande almost thousande yeares ere ye borne feckenhas reasonable demaud therfore remayneth vnanswered foule absurdyte obiecteth vnauoyded appereth well dede silence vnauoydable diuision pag fekenham foloweth resolution foresayde scruple made l bishop vvinchester resolute ansvvere saide scruple expressed forenamed poinctes l sayde muche lamente right meaninge othe beene season opened declared vnto whan onely lacke right vnderstanding thereof hath bene cause stay distourbance co science whereas q maiesties meaning othe farre otherwise tha expresse word lie verbatim like doth well appeare highnes interpretatio made thereof iniunctios therevnto obiectio vndoutedly highnes fully meane mind claim take al spiritual gouernmet vpo besides expres wordes othe whervnto al bound swere verbatim lie without al chaunge alteratio making word sense thereof highnes interpretation set spiritual gouernmet lesse much euery point without exception answere l still continue deniall thereof highnes meaning take much spiritual authority power vppon affirmation moste certainly assuredly chapter concerning resolution horne gaue fekenham forenamed poyntes stapleton processe following standeth vppon certain resolution horne fekeha saieth horne denieth therefore quaestio facti cal yt doubte restinge vpon priuate talke passed betwene ca geue certaine iudgmet must referre yt discrete consideratio indifferet reader yet muche know wil say vnderstande suche haue seueral time comunicatio sayde fekenha emong thinges conference heard fekenha say touching theis resolution hath daniel secretary horne hand writing redie shewed tymes yt yt likely daniel wil testifie truth case shoulde required whose hand writing fekenha saieth hath also certaine thinges copied yet euent thing come vncertaine let v imagine vnlikely case daniel wil deny forsaied writing horne much sharply vehemetly crie resolution doth none lyke forged false feyned maliciouse much like matter laieth forth defence nowe suerly though fekenham lyke haue therbye great preiudice principal matter whether resolution true false principal point neither greatly bettered much hindred yet fekenha perchaunce greatly impayre honesty good name therby let v said thinck vpo worst whether fekenham hath ye haue heard much good defence principall pointe may distresse fynde good reliefe defending sauing vpright honesty ye wil perchauce good reader thinck fekenha hard ad strayt case yt great difficulty find apparat honest help yet al ther good great helpe hade wil bolde self one take vppo self make sufficient proufe resolution fekenhams horne owne yf secretary serue wil bring forth one witnes shalbe meaning othe farre otherwise expresse wordes statute lie verbatim thinges therefore gentle vnderstanding interpreted mollified therfore thoughe wordes statute general precise onely supreame gouernour perswade reader fekenham hath slaundered saieth right sense othe none yt plainely set forth saith supremacie onely quenes highnes exclusiue onely ca haue sense meaning saith moreouer adde supreamacie scripture playn contrary likely therfore conference fekenham ye forsee mischief therfor though ye deny stifly ye gaue dede resolution specified suerly thig probable ye make resolution hym euen answere also doe ye expressely say fewe leaues fol prince neither may claime preache word god minister sacramentes bynde lose ye say fol spirituall gouernement rule belonging onely bishop church ruler ye confesse within leaues followinge lyke bisshoppes haue spirituall iurisdistion ouer theire flocke expresse worde god thereby prince haue maner spiritual gouerment agreable resolutios fekenham saith thereof c hereof ariseth particular negatiue spiritual cause vnder supreme gouernement prince let v cosider kind opposition two proposition repugne thus stande opposition spirituall cause without clause largely collect thereby king quenes realm may challege authority ad power ministerie diuine office church doth agree resolution therefore cause worlde ye deny say falsly slaunderouslye fayned oprely apperteyning office calling vvithout commission authority prince povver distinction made ecclesiastical iurisdiction vvil first repete put mine ansvveare argumentes spiritual iurisdiction secrete courte conscience secrete courte consciece vntruthe neither preaching ghospell ministration sacrament referred iurisdiction cohibitiue author alleaged preachinge ghospell ministration sacrametes absoluing reteininge sinnes vvoorde god publique mynistery therfore call cohibityue bicause court conscience man bound lovvsed vnvvillingly vvill exercise kind iurisdictio neither kinges ciuill magistrate neither persone may challendge take vppon onlesse lavvfully called thereunto iurisdiction cohibityue hath vntruthe suche diuision cohibityue iurisdiction tvvo partes one consisteth exercise excommunication circumstaunces thereunto required christes institution vvhich povver iurisdiction belongeth church onely vntruthe excommunication properly belongeth bisshops prince bishoppe priest man hath authority excommunicate onely churche vvho receiue authority therevnto commission church kinde cohibitiue iurisdiction povver authority consisteth exercised foro causarum courte cause apperteineth ad externum publicum forum externall publike courte defined saith antonius authority povver declare lavv geue sentence iudge controuersies pertayninge courte vvhat euery man righte summe doo thinges iustice dooth require accordinge lavves ioannes quintinus defineth iurisdiction effect openeth nature therof plainely saying iurisdictio office authority declare law admynister iustice equity gouern people right ad lawes wha name office saith meane iurisdictio hath selfe necessity declare lawe office euery man bound doo declare lawe exercise iudgementes wherevppon commeth iurisdiction meaneth iurisdiction hath name called exercising iudgementes iudgementes exercised onelye haue iurisdictio power iudge iurisdiction consisteth contention debating matter courte iudgements authority iudge dooth discende nowe vntruthe quintinus speaketh temporall iurisdiction ecclesiasticall prince alone whome power vertue vntruthe antonius falsified speaketh iurisdiction vvhich cometh prince onely iurisdiction saith antonius churche minister accordinge theire office rightly enioyned vnto may lawfully visite enquire men manner punishe faulty send foorth apparitours sommoners cyte sturdy stubborne represse malepartnes call sommon meete personnes synode prouinciall generall confirme matter decreed synode coucell vntruthe great deale left midle plainly confutinge horn purpose pardone faultes chaunge mitigate penauce enioyned confessed faultes condemne heretiques writinges examine men writinges euer set foorth published due examination iudge whether conteyne sounde pestilent doctrin ordeine decree lawes ceremony rytes constitute bisshoppes church minister also depose degrade make irreguler vnhable haue holy order determine illegitimation personnes maryage bestowe ecclesiasticall benefice exact tythes annates many thinges may lavvfully doone haue povver cohybitiue iurisdiction saith properly signified name keyes although may named respect church key yet differeth much keyes first courte courte conscience vse keyes occupied courte conscience belongeth onely euangelicall priestes iurisdiction may lawfully exercised minister woorde sacramentes priestes tvvo former partes ecclesiastical iurisdiction haue vertue povver institution christe immediatly euen third part vvhich saied consist foro causarum vvith thing vvhich may vsed exercised vertu thereof doth depende vpon vntruthe author antonius calleth opinion impiu errore vvicked errour positiue lavves christian magistrats vvhere vvanteth vpo positiue rule order church vvhere order must practised immediatly vpon lavve god chapter howe horne restraineth othe one kinde iurisdiction thereby auoide fekenhams vnuincible argument taken god woorde stapleton amonge obiections fekenham made supremacy conference waltham one bisshops warrante commission exercise spiritual function office expresse woorde god therefore could quiet conscience allowe othe geueth prince supremacy cause spiritual al priuileges preheminences wise touching spirituall iurisdiction mislikethan ansvvere io anto delphin io anthonius delde potesta eccles venet bisshops hauing commission god worde may visite reforme cure throughout booke ful many made meane vpo one diuers particular coclud affirmatiuely vniuersal say euil consequent haue al proufes coclusios ben booke hitherto suche prince called councell inuestured bishoppes deposed bishoppes made constitution ecclesiasticall ergo suche prince supreme gouernours al ecclesiastical cause say haue proued absolutely pricely authority haue missed al proufes well appereth indifferent reader peruser bothe writinges saie case proued antecedets good allwaies consequent say vpon one diuers particular conclude affirmatiuely vniuersal one emperour prince amonge many longe succession diuers countres haue brought forthe whose example sufficiente enumeration partes might logiquely reasonably coclude affirmatiue vniuersal supreme gouernement al spiritual ecclesiastical thinges cause haue horne brought one suche shewe one allowe come nowe charge fekenham thys foule euil consequent thought preuention blame fekenha might escape therby blame selfe thought shoulde haue forgotten charge herewith excepte selfe charging put v minde thereof vpon imagined conclusion feckenhams induce dilemma whether conclusion folow folow yet shal alwaies remayne absurdite say neuer made consequent also foloweth say conclusion folowe cosequetly vpon antecedent haue ye concluded nothing al christes diuinity may matter ye haue taken hande proue answere feckenham hereby fully cocludeth principall purpose commission spiritual gouernement geuen reasoneth expresly cofesse bishop immediatly god christ selfe true god euen principall spirituall cause fede church true hath already geauen apostle successours bishop priestes churche without comission authorisatio prince earth whatsoeuer god hath self say horn geue bisshops sufficiet comission discharge cure therfore letter patent sawe great impiety bishop pastours god lawe ordayned suche office oftener exercise office lenger remaine saied office please prince time authorise allowe therefore men selues doubte true subiectes quenes highnes well willers maiest person refused yet othe aboue saied conclusion horne fowle absurdity take othe supreme gouernemente al spiritual thinges cause othe also say nothing may excepted fol except al owne wordes yet make nowe limitatio except many principall cause ecclesiasticall say also prince hath gouernement bishop hauing sufficient commission herein god selfe whereas ecclesiastical euseb lib cap vide decr epist antheri among touching translation bishop iewell helpe yowe pinche like trusty frende newe shi te wil pleade vppon state inficial denying vtterly old decretal epistle among stand vppon foggy false ground saieth md harding dothievvel reply pag set fast foting vppon sure infallible reason antherus epistle making mention bishoppes felix eusebius borne al time antherus lyued borne great holde vide sab aenead lib yf alleage sabellicus though good chronicler well allowed latin man make epistle authenticall perchaunce ye would cry say partiall ad papist wil therfore prouide grecian late grecian ye shal haue cause refuse suspected niceph li c nicephorus may wel appeare grecian toke decree authentical also shal ye find expresse mention sayd eusebius felix ye shall also find notable place authority sea rome ye impugne translation must authorised pope assent confirmation seing nicephorus papist ye call one owne writer knowe latin grecian infected also theire schisme yet withstanding thing catholyke full newe heresy respect content take one writer woulde see vantage ye take hande prouf fowle false paradoxe yf ye proue thinge relief paradoxe ye must proue christian bisshops vnder roman empyre authority iudge exercise iurisdictio ouer theyr clergy commissio graunt costantinus let v heare nicephorus self euery may see ye possible stretche without bursting ioyne ought conclude qua vero imperator constantinus obseruantia erga professionem fidei nostrae fuerit niceph li cap abunde illud quoque testatur quod clericos omnes constitutione lata immune liberos que esse permisit iudicium que iurisdictionem eos episcopis si quidem ciuilium iudicum cognitione declinare vellet madauit quod episcopi iudicassent id robur authoritatem sententiae omnino habere debere decreuit firma quoque immutabilia esse voluit quae synodis constituta essent quae ab episcopis iudicata forent vt ea magistratibus rempublicam administrantibus militarique quae sub eis essent manu exequutioni mandarentur que ad rem collata perficerentur constituit thing also saieth nicephorus doth abundantly testifievvhat maner iurisdiction costantin gaue bishopes honour reuerence beare toward faith ordeyned lawe making clergie shoulde free exempted fro paying tribute case would refuse iudgement temporall magistrate bishop haue iurisdictio vpon geue sentence cause sayed episcopall iudgement haue ful strength authority ordeined also thinges decreed synode bishopes stande stronge immutable bishoply iudgement put execution ciuil magistrate helpe suche souldiers vnderneath stretche nowe horne conclusion ye without bursting haue lawe constantine clergie may choose whether wil answere matter euer laie man may wil cause matter deuolued bisshop neuer word ecclesiastical matter constatine geueth bishop iurisdiction neither one woorde bishoppes neither summon councelles make ecclesiastical lawes without prince consent plaine ordinaunce lay magistrate shal see synodical decree shall put execution wherby contrary conclusion ye mainteine answere well appeareth prince part onely see ecclesiasticall decree made bishop kept put vre haue necessarie consente allowing disallowing appeareth also euidently eusebius writing constantine sort euseb li cap de vita constant quae ab episcopis publicis conuentibus editae erant regulae sua consignabat confirmabat authoritate signed confirmed authoritie suche canon rule bisshoppes assembly decreed though without royall assente canon shoulde haue beene voide authoritie woulde make folke beleue eusebius writeth place ne reliquarum gentiu principibus liceret quae ab eis decreta essent abrogate intent lawful prince nation abrogate refuse bishop decree reason addeth immediatly cuiusuis enim iudicis sententiae sacerdotu dei iudiciu anteponendu esse emperour estemed iudgemet determination priest god preferred sentence euer iudgevvhat kinde iurisdiction theodosius carolus magnus gaue bisshops man therefore horn tel one fitte exa ple like gouernment mainteined quenes highnes person al inheritours realme england constantine set clergie liberty whether would answere secular court noble emperour theodosius set wel al laitie clergie like libertie ordeined vide c quicuque etc volumus q quicuque litem habens siue petitor fuerit alias siue reus vel cursis temporum curriculis siue cum negotium peroratur siue cum iam coeperit promi sente tia si iudiciu elegerit sacrosanctae sedis tistitis ilico sine aliqua dubitatione etiam si par alia refragatur ad episcoporum iudicium cum sermone litigantium dirigatur petrus bertrandus libello de iurisdictione ecclesiasticae sed dice quod ista lex est abrogata vt videtur tangere glosa ibidem sed hoc non valet quia licet ista lex non fuerit corpore iuris redacta tamen propter hoc est abrogata imo c cosider hovv hadsomly horn alleageth bertradus vide horne fol plaintife cause time sentence might breake ordinary iudge bring matter whether defendat would episcopal audience ordinaunce great charles aboute yeares renewed inuiolably obserued subiectes wel romaine frenchemen almanes bauarians saxon turingias frisons galles britanes lombard gascons beneuentanes gothes spaniard ye constantinus magnus doe ye theodosius magnus carolus magnus constitution bringing forth blind cacus denne dasel bleare reader withal iurisdictione ecclesiastica petrus bertrandus say bisshop cardinal one best learned men canon ciuil lawes suerly may petrus cugne ius thoughe ye auace worthy knight go hide head corner againste folishe fonde arguing againste ecclesiastical liberty booke writen haue declaredconsider ha somly horne alleageth bertrandus wherfore tale bishop held iurisdiction ouer theire clergy constantine resolute answere first quarrelleth worde priestes purposeconcerning vvorde prieste argumente remaining sownde whole called priestes called elder though worde minister like horne well yet worde elder signifie elder age proper significatio greke word yet scripture signifieth office dignitie man cal priesthod elder priest withall yet alwaies called age appereth timothee yong truth word greke nonlatin alphabet sometime signifieth inferior dignitie vnder bishoppe sometime bishop sometime woorde apostolus signifieth none xij apostle bishop one confounded scripture whereof theodoretus vndoubted witnesse thus writeth theodoret comme tar epi tim phil eosdem olim vocabant presbyteros episcopos eos autem qui nunc vocantur episcopi nominabant apostolos procedente autem tempore nomen confirmation sacrament holy ghost thereby geuen hiero cont lucifer si hoc loco quaeras qui ecclesia baptizatus nisi per manus episcopi non accipiat spiritum sanctum disce hanc obseruatione ex authoritate descendere quod post ascensum domini spirit ad apostolos de endit multis locis ide factitatu reperimus august contra literas petiliani lib cap neither chrysostomus whome ye recite auncient authour auoucheth baptized afterward co firmed bisshop ad receiued holy ghost visible signes hierome plainely testifieth augustine confesseth sacrament baptisme holy ghost geuen without outward miracle speaketh fekenham one worde miracle wherefore misshapen argument ye bring forth ouerthrowe folishe fonde argument aunswere neuer none blinde ignorantly brought vp monastery westminster could well perceyue il fauored kinde reasoning neuer vsed amonge catholikes answere fekeham touching second allegation actes mete ghospelling prelate leaue reasoning fal rayling elude reader expectation argument euer shalbe able answere yet like cunning diuine verie skilfull visitourm horn extraordinary rayling processe teacheth v two visitation one scripturely forinsecall canon lawe visitation haue longe lesson one socius shoulde haue sayde socinus person may visite matter owght enquire vppon visitation effecte doth nothing else extrauagant declaration mocke mowe like diuelles iacke anapes potteth good rite customes vsages catholike churche blessed sacrament solaceth selfe pleasantly maketh ioly sporte poore sir iohn lacke latin could tell whether say corpum meum corpus meus length concludeth full solemnelie neither person exercise canonicall visitation matter enquired founde scripture bare title visitours vnlesse bisshoppe yet canon lawe bisshoppes haue called bisshoppes neither vnlesse may ciuill lawe bisshops asmuche say li tit de muneribus honoribus act clerkes market howe thinke good reader maister fekenham argument grounded vpon plaine scripture doinges paule visite christian commaunded kepe lawes ordinaunces apostle made without laical commission scripturely prelatelyke greate scriptured man soluted thinke man hath reuerence god regard either matter reader thinke man lacketh much witte doth vertue learning religion true deuotion malice putte one eie catholikes putteth owne eies tell faulte catholikes redoundeth double treble self affinitie amonge wil dispose thing come place fekenham groundeth self vpo therevpon augustine thinketh whiche vniformely generally vsed throughout christendome touching order administration sacrament haue ben ordeined like doinges christia emperour haue passed vvithout admonition misliking acknovvledged authority lavvful commaunded bisshops euery vvhere asseble appointmet vvher vvha vvould sharply reproueth donatistes bisshoppes assembled nicen councell commaundement vvhom ye speake acknovvledged emperour haue authority iudge cause vntruthe el foloweth many somtymes called iudge betvvene party vvho yet haue authoritye ouer party el doone folishly offer billes complaint vnto vvhome thought authority might iudge determine case vvere true prince might iudge priestes cause vvhat conclude thereof conclude purpose good consequent constantinus vvould could lavvfully iudge priestes assembled nicen councel ergo vntruthe ergo ovvne fekenhams bishoppes priest may cal councels make lavves order emperours constantin greate valentian first theodosius firste stapleton although fekeha hath alredy layd forth holy scripture sufficiet shew ad proue superiority al cause ecclesiastical doth rest laye prince spiritual ruler yet nowe adde adioyne therunto forcible argument shall beate downe ground horne newe laicall supremacy horne al witte cunning goeth auaunce new supremacy depresse abolish contrary scripture iniuriouse emperours prince nowe stoppe lyinge mouth fekenham bringeth forth thre worthiest emperours euer al thre lyuing christian religion florished plaine wordes confesse cleargies superiority behalf constantine great valentinian first theodosius greatconstantine acknowledgeth cleargies superiority constantine request siluester pope called first general councell nice diuerse bisshops contention certain matter offered complaint constantine answered god made priest geuen authority iudge ouer therefore might well iudges ex ruff lib eccles hist cap ye sayth may iudged man good lorde farre discrepant iudgment noble contry chronicler cal worthy emperour iudgement horn fellowes disclaimeth flatly newe superiority yet nowe one thousand almost thre hudred yeares preaching writing yea premunire sword maintaine answere presseth horne sore therefore seketh euery corner hide head yet fynd good quiet resting place firste would fain take holde matter constantin cal councel siluester request councell tyme siluester iulius deny argument horne must neades bishop reparing nice fro al quarter christendome haue conuenient time come thither li c nicephorus writeth sermone acclamatorio ad imperatorem act fo co arrius diuisor atque partitor trinitatis insurgebat continuo costantinus semper augustus siluester laudabilis magnam atque insigne nicea synodum congregabant proufe syluester called councel able bring least two rather thre hundred witness ad worst shall bishop aucient withal none liued yeres perchauce ye thik iest truely horne meane plaine reader belieue pope ad bishop acknowledg costantins supremacy calling coucels ye say principal part iurisdictio ecclesiastical cohibitiue vntrue bare calling councel principal part haue declared vntrue also vide fol lib ye say pope called councell theis string weake therefore sone broken ye see setteth thirde weakest wurst al stringe hangeth vppon foolishe synnefull ciuylity policy maister horne imagineth full fondly worthy prince constantine thowghe spake wordes modesty onely policie prudent forsighte least siftinge priuate quarells mighte haue hindred common cause thoughte authority mighte stretche farre iudge priest therefore thoughe politykely relented time yet afterwarde councel tyrus shewed hym selfe supreame iudge cause ecclesiasticall wont sayed horne maledicta glosa quae destruit textum cursed glose destroyeth text suerly ye imprudently ouersene answere peuishe wretched policy wherewith dishonour noble monarch ye haue forgotten rule aswell diuinity policy policy somtyme dissemble truth tel vntruthe time synne yea though truth offensiue man officiable profitable many augustin doth large discourse matter aug ad consentiu de madatio tom emperour priest iudge doth constantins saying conteyne plaine lye seing expressely confessed iudges sayd farder coulde iudged man leaue policie therfore prudent forsight generatio vnmete either constantine much meaner churche ambrose mette hym forbadde enter moste vehementlie reprouing hym sayed shawghter asking howe coulde finde conscience eyher lyfte vp hys handes god defiled suche foule murther receyue holie bodie christe receyue hys mouthe preciouse bloude christe whose furiouse ragnge commaundemente muche bloude bene shedde wherefore woulde emperour shoulde turne home againe shoulde pacientlie suffer bondeof penaunce emperour enioyned ambrose god heauenly sentence allowed meaning sentence excommunication emperour one browght vppe goddes lawes obeyed hym weapinge teares departed continued eight monethes neuer came thys churche receyued sacramente christes bodie solemne feast christmasse nowe come great heuines sorowe mihi porro non modo id tangere licet verum etiam coelum ipsum clausum est neque enim diuini illius oraculi non memini quod disertis verbis statuit quaecunque sacerdotibus dei ligata fuerint terris ea etia coelis certa esse ligata consider euery poore begger might goe churche onelie shutte owte full bitterlie complayned moned selfe excluded onelie churche heauen also well remember christe sayde plainlie euer bownde earthe goddes priestes shoulde bownde also heauen lengthe sent ruffinus noble man entreat ambrose went self neither yet would presume enter vntill ambrose absolued losed bodes te autem oro vt vincula mea soluas et mox tuae vero vir diuine id est saieth sayinge forbadde enter addinge wordes inwarde partes priestes caetera caetera declareth fekenha meante bare ingresse ingresse tarying withall accordinge story doth referre selfe caetera therfore cause shoulde vntruely reporte yt making nothing purpose againste consideringe maner vtterance yt truely reported ye mayster horne shewe selfe wrangler poynte though dede theodoretus saieth reherse nonlatin alphabet scarsly hardlye yet leauing owte two syllable way beneficial fekenham preiudiciall cause worthie noted vntruth yt true theodosius learned difference betwixt themperour priestes thoughe scarslye hardlye longe time nowe haue proued fekenham honeste man cleared geue warninge see self prouide aswel selfe honesty ye shall neuer doe remeber pray vide supra fol b story theodosius maketh manie pointes horne doctrine aduantage great honesty ye toke alleaging theodosius doings take hede say least story yet one againe put much shame wil tarry vppon incidente though great matter story geueth sure recorde testimony againste synagoges rather barnes aswell plucking downe chauncell makinge difference betwene priestes lay men place also taking away oblation presence sentence bishoppe excluded church heauen also wil discourse whether storie aptly brought foorth fekenhams purpose ye denie doth see euidentlie storie proueth ambrose cause ecclesiastical haue bene head church millaine emperour neuer see truth long liueth like faire sunny daie stoppeth eye handes midnoone crieth fooles saie daie lighte euery man may easely see storie tenour othe possiblie euident absurditie though ye dare confesse plaine wordesm horn starting hole vvhen pressed mere yet haue declared may wel gathered selfe doe like therfore ye craftelie wind selfe much ye may possiblie haue cohibitiue first cohibitiue ye call sette fast footing ioyne issue first first cohibitiue iurisdiction ye call comprehended excomunication whiche ye see practised without prince commission yea vppon prince selfe man euer read hearde ambrose commission either prince churche excommunicate theodosius likely whole church congregation millaine woulde agree excomunication emperour authoritie man may doubte whether one laie man priest courage herein ioyne ambrose dagerous yet worthy enterprise surely ambrose none comission bisshops sithens haue none say excomunicated seruant erle stillico paulinus vita ambrosij forging false letter excomunication wrought woderously waxed mad possessed diuel began al teare none excomunicated also maximus tyrat ibidem without great daunger life niceph li cap vinculum quod deus coelitus sub calculo comprobauit suscipe none say receiued god made bishope iurisdiction ambrose exercise supreame ecclesiasticall authoritie vppon higest monarche al world episcopal office ambros lib epistola ad ipsum theodosium ita deus ab omnibus tribulationibus liber quia non ab homine neque per hominem sed aperte mihi interd ctu aduerti dum enim essem sollicitus ipsa nocte qua proficisci parabam venisse quidem visus e sed mihi sacrificium offerre non licuit yet without plaine celestiall reuelation encourage hym therto confirme selfe declareth herein doinges agreable teachinges taught catholikes excommunication perteyneth bishopes ad multitud bishop office sayth maybe heale canckered foystered soores may cut perniciouse rotten partes quite true principle bisshops neede looke none warrant excomunicate man deserueth excomunication prince neither putting case ye falsely head church therfore either muste take thys vnnatural monstrouse head officiorum lib ca sic episcopi affectus boni est vt optet sanare infirmos serpentia auferre vulnera adurere aliqua non abscindere postremo quod sanari non potest cum dolore abscindere ye sette two heades vpon one bodie ye muste graunte authoritie excommunicat maruell preaching teaching true sure ye make learned men theodosius could espie ye bene elbowe haue enspired whith litle newe diuinitie ye might haue wonderfullie eased woful harte perchance might haue proued doctrine haue worne labour pope triple croune theodosius good helpe suche good seruice greate distresse sort dolt theodosius mighty prince none could tell neded passe butte ambrose excomunicatio vnlesse saw yt withal sealed whole congregation yf theodosius learned lesson would haue shifted wel inough felfe neded haue pined away many moneths cotinual mourning lamentatio suerly yf ye tolde horne would haue take ye lier heretike haue sayed brought vp knowledge god law ad knew ful wel niceph li cap adeo religiosus theodosius fuit vita que suam accuratissime ad diuinas leges co posuit laufully excommunicated ambrose whiche muche feare pronounced bishop onely hath therto ordinary deuotio life co formable god lawes none authority al therefore time excommunicated froward mok hauing none authority therto would neither eat drink vntil wer assoiled yea though tharchbishop self costatinople offred assoil come cohibitiue ye cal yt authority making lawes decree euidently proued story whense commeth order maner distincte chauncell bodie churche place priestes one laity bishop without commission prince people order lawe ye see ambrose appointed prince hym selfe euer afterward kepte thoughe vsed cotrary againe doth ambrose prescribe theodosius penaunce certain lawe order set forth proclamation thirdly law made bishop councel without commission prince people coc mileuit c sentence one geuen order taken matter ecclesiastical none clergy appeale vpon paine depriuation ciuile prince go storie time theodosius ambrose coc concil aquil ambrose whole councell kept aquileia depose palladius among thing would haue certaine noble men haue ben associate sitte iudgement bishop time theodosius art fol haue spoken largely returne c iewell thus ye perceiue good reader aptly fitly fekenham hath accommodated purpose story three emperours poore shift maister horne driuen maintenance euill cause hath taken hand defend thus see also storie ambrose theodosius horne hathe answered one word making short recitall thereof stealeth faire away without answere fekenham diuision pag cal institut cap iohn caluine intreating history betwixte emperor valetinian theodosius ambrose log processe wherin maketh good prouf spiritual iurisdictio doth appertain vnto church vnto empire hath woordes folowing qui vt magistratum ornet ecclesiam spoliant hac potestate non modo falsa interpretatione christi sententia corrumpunt sed sanctos omnes episcopos qui tam multi tempore apostolorum extiterunt non leuiter damnant quod honorem officiuque magistratus falso praetextu sibi vsurpauerit spoil church authority therby adorn temporal magistrate onely corrupting christ appointment meaning therin also lightly codemne set naught al holy bishop great number haue continued fro time apostle hitherto honour office spiritual gouernmet haue saith iohn caluin vsurped taken vpon false pretext title made therof againe iohn caluin saith cal ca amos qui initio tantopere extulerunt henricum regem angliae certe fuerunt homines incosiderati dederut illi summa omniu potestate et hoc semper grauiter vulnerauit erant enim blasphemi cum vocarent ipsum summu caput ecclesiae sub christo beginning much extoll henry king england geue vnto highest authoritie church men lacked circumspection small consideration thing saith iohn caluin time first kind cohibitiue iurisdictio caluin double quadruple yea much vvrong citing sentence ye haue vntruely reported circumstance sentence haue hackte beginning thereof one material vvorde part haue obscurely tanslated part falsly altering vvords sense ye haue belied slaundered auncient bisshopes haue auouched caluin vvere vvordes meaning vvhich translation father vppon directly selfe vvhich meant ye thought suppose cunningly handeled haue serued turne euil dealing vvith caluin proceeded ignoraunce latine vvas fine grosse vnderstanding ye somevvhat borne vvithall haue thus dealt purpose order decree c reason amisse seing iudgement learned vnder power binding loosing power making lawes contayned also reason forceth haue skill make lawes order directing men conscience whose whole study office consisteth instructing refourming men conscience maister fekenham doth reason thus blasphemy call prince heade church ergo maister fekenham saufe conscience take othe supremacy prince supreme head againe prince hath authority iurisdiction binde lose excommunicate ergo fekenham persuaded swere statute annexeth vniteth al iurisdiction prince swere prince supreme gouernour cause hastie vpon wyll geue breathing tyme seue yeres least life long name robert horne ye shall neuer able soyle neither thinke matter suche importance wise men haue feare god eies wil carried away heresie contineweth obiection vnanswered yet presse litle haue eies shut light shal vnderstad iohn caluin offended brethern englad also germany yea neighbor attributing prince spirituall gouernemet horn auoucheth fol principall parte prince royall power booke leafe noted saith sed interea sunt homines inconsiderati qui faciut illos nimis spirituales caluin vbi supra et hoc vitium passim regnat germania etiam regionibus nimium grassatur et nunc sentimus quales fructus nascantur ex illa radice quod scilicet principe et quicunque potiuntur imperio putent se ita spirituales esse vt nullum sit amplius ecclesiasticum regimen et hoc sacrilegium apud eos grassatur quia non possunt metiri suum officium certis legitimis finibus sed non putant posse se regnare nisi aboleat omnem ecclesiae authoritate sint summi iudices tam doctrina quam toto spirituali regimine meane vnaduised person doe make meaneth lay prince spirituall ouersight rayneth germany countres also procedeth ouermuch nowe feele fruytes springe vp roote verely prince al beare rule think selues nowe spirituall ecclesiastical gouernemet sacrilege taketh place among bicause measure office within certayn lawful boundes persuaded kingdome nothinge except abolish authority church become selues supreme iudges wel doctrine al kinde spirituall gouernement hitherto iohn caluin feckenham catholike subiecte england said write much fol b would haue charged horn vnkind meaning prince ad state yea say fol b bereueth spolyeth prince principall part royall power caluin saith man onely estemed authorised also farre aboue sayd saye horne possybly deuise say calleth yt plaine sacrilege prince measure limit power must become supreme iudges ecclesiasticall gouernement doe horne defend prince onely may oughte also supreme epist ad solitariam vitam agentes hosius episcopus cordubensis qui synodo nicenae primae interfuit sic habet sicut testatur athanasius aduersus constantium imp si istud est iudicium episcoporum quid commune cum eo habet imperator sin contra ista mini caesaris conflantur quid opus est hominibus titulo episcopis quando condito aeuo auditum quando iudicium ecclesiae authoritatem suam ab imperatore accepit aut quando vnquam pro iudicio agnitum plurimae antehac synodi fuerunt multa iudicia ecclesiae habita sunt sed neque patres istiusmodi re principi persuadere conati sunt nec princeps se rebus vvoorde bringeth saying reason vvhich goeth athanasius findeth self greeued many godly bisshops truth selfe suffered much cruelty vvere vvrongfully condemned according order ecclesiastical iudgement vvhat iudge kind iudgmet prince shuld shevve self busy curious ecclesiastical thing vvil ad pleasure shuld rule guyde steade god vvoord godly canos father costatius vvould haue bisshops aria vvhich vvere bisshops deede athanasius saith much lesse apt iudge matter touchig principal article faith faithful bisshop athanasi takig heresy vndoubted truth might called questio sought al meanes haue athanasi codened al bisshops refuse comunio co municate vvith arians disorderly dealigs theperour athanasi codeneth directly agaist order ecclesiastical sessio synode hovv euer preteded vnder colour bisshoply iudgemet abuse ovvn povver authority ovvne luste vvhom vvoulde vvould haue seeme ignoraut athanasius mynd place vvere denie prince vntruth medle beare supreme rule synod athanasius denyeth doings doe maitayn li c medle deale ecclesiasticall thinges cause vvhich farre fro meaning self vvith many godly bisshops haue shevved acknovvledge prince authority herein epistle self cofesseth emperours authority cal coucels citeth hosius also vvho enclineth purpose confessing constans constantinus perours cal al bisshops councel vvhich calleth sardicese consilium accusation crime laid athanasius theodoretus affirmeth emperour costantius called synode millaine like matter vvhose calling faithful bishop assembled parentes regio edicto obeying kinges summons vvhich vvould haue done beene man saith vnlavvfull haue doinges haue al gouernmet othe pronouceth vnlavvful haue dooings councelles vvhen abused authority councel though povver beene absolute vvithout limites boundes vvilling yea compelling doo vvill good consciencience vvould obey quin etiam palam praesentem regem coarguebat impij iniusti imperij openly reproue king wicked vniust rule co maundement vvherby manifest athanasius speaketh vntruth athanasi reproueth vtterly price authority ecclesiasticall cause prince authority ecclesiastical matter tiranny abusing authority vvhich god hath geue vvhervvith mynister vnto god vvil rule ovvne luste commende authority reproue disorderly abuse thereof novv let v see hovv saying athanasius helpeth cause constantius emperour dealt vnorderly ovvne lust athanasius others pretending neuerthelesse iudgement bisshops vvhich athanasius misliketh plaine place auouched ergo bisshoppes priestes may make lavves decree order exercise second kind cohibitiue iurisdiction ouer flockes cure vvithout commission prince authority doubt yee see faulte sequele yee vntruthe ovvne sequele fekenhams least ye ought ashamed therof chap conteyning confutation horne answer made woordes athanasius stapleton nowe one allegation fekenham proposed athanasius hosius bisshop corduba saith fekenham present first nicene councel hath wordes athanasius writing emperour constantius doth testifie athanasius epist ad solitaria vitam age te yf iudgement bisshops hath emperour one contrary parte yf thinges wrought threates menace emperour neade anye men besides beare bare title bisshoppes beginning worlde hath bene heard iudgement churche toke authority emperour hath tyme bene agnised iudgement many synodes haue ben tyme many councels hath church holden tyme yet come athan epist ad solit vitam agentes either father went persuade prince matter prince shewed selfe curiouse matter churche nowe haue spectacle neuer sene browght arrius heresye heretikes emperour constantius assembled may vnder colour title bisshops vse power whome pleaseth horne allegation aunswereth fekenham doth athanasius threfolde wronge c first wronge replie putting case hosius word athanasius fekenhams matter nothing thereby hindered rather furthered considering excellent authority athanasius hath euer churche hosius hath euen said epistle athanasius one leaf much like sentence proceding couragious godly boldenes medle syr emperour saieth forsayed constantius matter ecclesiastical neither comaund v parte rather learne thinges v god hath committed empire v thing appertaine churche therefore ath indict epist ad solit euen maligneth spiteth empire doeth contrarie god ordinance take ye head least ye medling matter church doe runne greate offence whereas second wrong done athanasius say fekenham hath lefte one material word athanasius ye haue turned worde one halfe hundred wordes nedelesse declaration space one whole leafe least yet neuer come nigh matter beside wisedome ye alleage extraordinarie glose epistle ambrose doth co firme fekenhams present allegation quado audisti cleme ti imperat causa fidei laicos de episcopo iudicasse et mox certe si vel scripturarum seriem diuinarum vel vetera tempora retractemus quis est qui abnuat causa fidei causa inqua fidei episcopos solere de imperatoribus non imperatores de episcopis iudicare agreable valetinia whose sonne enduced thereto arrian bishop auxe tiu woulde nedes call bishop benche iudge ouer made expresse lawe matter faithe ambros lib epi ibidem ecclesiastical order iudge neither office vnequal neither right vnlike ambrose selfe expoundeth sacerdotes de sacerdotibus voluit iudicare woulde haue priestes iudge ouer priestes matter ecclesiastical faithe saieth ambrose si alias argueretur episcopus moru esset examinanda causa etia hanc voluit ad episcopale iudiciu pertinere otherwise also bishop accused question touching maners examined question also emperour woulde haue belonge trial iudgement bishop haue yt belongeth prince iudges vppon priest either matter faith either matter touching liuing ners doth vtterly destroy al new primacy late acte parliament deposing world hitherto xi hodred yeres ad god thaked hath digested wel inough tyl late new apostle luther ad calui ca neither abide chrysosto saith ad truly matt priest mediatour betwen god ad v christ hiself
